text: File headers are used to identify a file by examining the first 4 or 5 bytes of its hexadecimal content.
ani file header: 52 49 46 46 (ASCII: RIFF)
au file header: 2E 73 6E 64 (ASCII: snd)
bmp file header: 42 4D F8 A9 (ASCII: BM)
bmp file header: 42 4D 62 25 (ASCII: BMp%)
bmp file header: 42 4D 76 03 (ASCII: BMv)
cab file header: 4D 53 43 46 (ASCII: MSCF)
dll file header: 4D 5A 90 00 (ASCII: MZ)
Excel file header: D0 CF 11 E0
exe file header: 4D 5A 50 00 (ASCII: MZP) - inno installer
exe file header: 4D 5A 90 00 (ASCII: MZ)
flv file header: 46 4C 56 01 (ASCII: FLV)
gif file header: 47 49 46 38 39 61 (ASCII: GIF89a)
gif file header: 47 49 46 38 37 61 (ASCII: GIF87a)
gz file header: 1F 8B 08 08
ico file header: 00 00 01 00
jpeg file header: FF D8 FF E1
jpeg file header: FF D8 FF E0 (ASCII: JFIF)
jpeg file header: FF D8 FF FE (ASCII: JFIF)
Linux bin file header: 7F 45 4C 46 (ASCII: ELF)
png file header: 89 50 4E 47 (ASCII: PNG)
msi file header: D0 CF 11 E0
mp3 file header: 49 44 33 2E (ASCII: ID3)
mp3 file header: 49 44 33 03 (ASCII: ID3)
OFT file header: 4F 46 54 32 (ASCII: OFT2)
PPT file header: D0 CF 11 E0
PDF file header: 25 50 44 46 (ASCII: %PDF)
rar file header: 52 61 72 21 (ASCII: Rar!)
sfw file header: 43 57 53 06/08 (ASCII: cws)
tar file header: 1F 8B 08 00
tgz file header: 1F 9D 90 70
Word file header: D0 CF 11 E0
wmv file header: 30 26 B2 75
zip file header: 50 4B 03 04 (ASCII: PK)
grep's strength is extracting information from text files. grep operates on one or multiple files when provided with a command line argument(s) that can also include wildcards.
grep example: grep "John" addressbook - Would return the lines that contained the "John" string in the addressbook text file
grep -A: Print number of lines after the match
grep -B: Print number of lines before match
grep -c: Report number of occurrences
grep -f: Reads one or more patterns from a file. Patterns are terminated by a newline
grep -h: Suppress the file names on the output
grep -i: Ignore case
grep -l: Report matching files, not matching lines
grep -P: Interpret pattern as a Perl Regex
grep -v: Reverse operation: return the lines not matching the string
The egrep (extended grep) utility can be used to match several possible strings at the same time (in an OR mode): egrep "John|Peter" addressbook or grep "John\|Peter" addressbook
sort, as its name implies, will sort the output.
sort -d: Uses dictionary order. Only letters, digits and blanks.
sort -n: will sort the output assuming it is numerical (instead of string)
sort -u: will remove redundant line, 'uniquing' the results

awk is an extremely useful tool, especially for parsing data structured in columns. It is straightforward to use for simple purposes. Its basic use is to select some particular columns from the output: column 1 is referred to as $1, column 2 as $2, etc.
The space is the default awk separator. However if you want to be able to parse data separated by some other character, e.g. ":", you can use the -F flag.
awk example: echo "hello:goodbye" | awk -F: '{print $2}' - Would return "goodbye" as an output
sed is an excellent command for character substitution.
sed example: echo "hallo" | sed 's/a/e/' - The output would be: hello
sed global modifier: You can use the g modifier to substitute all instances: echo "Hallo Janny" | sed 's/a/e/g' - The output would be: Hello Jenny
The uniq command reads the input and compares adjacent lines. If two or more adjacent lines are identical, all but one is removed.
uniq -c: Prefix line with number of occurrences
uniq -f: Avoid comparing the first N fields
uniq -i: Ignore case
uniq -s: Avoid comparing the first N characters
uniq -u: Only print unique lines
Returns the real date from epoch time: date -d @1284127201
Return an epoch time of 1288756800: date +%s -d "2010-11-03"
Return a 2 days old date: date --date="-2 days" +"%Y-%m-%d"
Return 20:00 hours: date -d @1288310401 +%k:%M
The Windows findstr has one interesting feature that differs from grep. If you need to search for multiple strings, you need to separate them with a space.
findstr example: findstr "WHITE GREEN" textfile - To search for WHITE or GREEN in a text file
To make the findstr search case insensitive, add the /I to print all variant of WHITE or GREEN.
findstr /B: Matches pattern if at the beginning of a line.
findstr /E: Matches pattern if at the end of a line.
findstr /L: Uses search strings literally.
findstr /R: Uses search strings as regular expressions.
findstr /S: Searches for matching files in the current directory and all subdirectories.
findstr /I: Specifies that the search is not to be case-sensitive.
findstr /X: Prints lines that match exactly.
findstr /V: Prints only lines that do not contain a match.
findstr /N: Prints the line number before each line that matches.
findstr /M: Prints only the filename if a file contains a match.
findstr /O: Prints character offset before each matching line.
findstr /P: Skip files with non-printable characters.
Forensic Analysts are on the front lines of computer investigations. This guide aims to support Forensic Analysts in their quest to uncover the truth.
The key to successful forensics is minimizing your data loss, accurate reporting, and a thorough investigation.
